statements.name: PROC DISCRIM
statements.description: For a set of observations containing one or more quantitative variables and a classification variable defining groups of observations, the DISCRIM procedure develops a discriminant criterion to classify each observation into one of the groups. The derived discriminant criterion from this data set can be applied to a second data set during the same execution of PROC DISCRIM. The data set that PROC DISCRIM uses to derive the discriminant criterion is called the training or calibration data set.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Activates all options that control displayed output.

arguments.name: ANOVA
arguments.description: Displays univariate statistics for testing the hypothesis that the class means are equal in the population for each variable.

arguments.name: BCORR
arguments.description: Displays between-class correlations.

arguments.name: BCOV
arguments.description: Displays between-class covariances.

arguments.name: BSSCP
arguments.description: Displays the between-class SSCP matrix

arguments.name: CANONICAL
arguments.description: Performs canonical discriminant analysis

arguments.name: CANPREFIX=
arguments.description: Specifies a prefix for naming the canonical variables. By default, the names are Can1, Can2, ..., Can. If you specify CANPREFIX=ABC, the components are named ABC1, ABC2, ABC3, and so on.

arguments.name: CROSSLIST
arguments.description: Displays the cross validation classification results for each observation

arguments.name: CROSSLISTERR
arguments.description: Displays the cross validation classification results for misclassified observations only.

arguments.name: CROSSVALIDATE
arguments.description: Specifies the cross validation classification of the input DATA= data set.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Specifies the data set to be analyzed. The data set can be an ordinary SAS data set or one of several specially structured data sets created by SAS/STAT procedures.

arguments.name: DISTANCE
arguments.description: Displays the squared Mahalanobis distances between the group means, F statistics, and the corresponding probabilities of greater Mahalanobis squared distances between the group means.

arguments.name: K=
arguments.description: Specifies a k value for the k-nearest-neighbor rule.

arguments.name: KERNEL=
arguments.description: Specifies a kernel density to estimate the group-specific densities. You can specify the KERNEL= option only when the R= option is specified. The default is KERNEL=UNIFORM.

arguments.name: BIWEIGHT
arguments.description: KERNEL=BIWEIGHT

arguments.name: EPANECHNIKOV
arguments.description: KERNEL=EPANECHNIKOV

arguments.name: NORMAL
arguments.description: KERNEL=NORMAL

arguments.name: TRIWEIGHT
arguments.description: KERNEL=TRIWEIGHT

arguments.name: UNIFORM
arguments.description: KERNEL=UNIFORM

arguments.name: KPROP=
arguments.description: Specifies a proportion, p, for computing the k value for the k-nearest-neighbor rule.

arguments.name: LIST
arguments.description: Displays the resubstitution classification results for each observation. You can specify this option only when the input data set is an ordinary SAS data set.

arguments.name: LISTERR
arguments.description: Displays the resubstitution classification results for misclassified observations only. You can specify this option only when the input data set is an ordinary SAS data set

arguments.name: MANOVA
arguments.description: Displays multivariate statistics for testing the hypothesis that the class means are equal in the population.

arguments.name: METHOD=
arguments.description: Determines the method to use in deriving the classification criterion.

arguments.name: NORMAL
arguments.description: A parametric method based on a multivariate normal distribution within each class is used to derive a linear or quadratic discriminant function.

arguments.name: NPAR
arguments.description: A nonparametric method is used and you must also specify either the K= or R= option.

arguments.name: METRIC=
arguments.description: Specifies the metric in which the computations of squared distances are performed.

arguments.name: DIAGONAL
arguments.description: PROC DISCRIM uses either the diagonal matrix of the pooled covariance matrix (POOL=YES) or diagonal matrices of individual within-group covariance matrices (POOL=NO) to compute the squared distances.

arguments.name: FULL
arguments.description: PROC DISCRIM uses either the pooled covariance matrix (POOL=YES) or individual within-group covariance matrices (POOL=NO) to compute the squared distances.

arguments.name: IDENTITY
arguments.description: PROC DISCRIM uses Euclidean distance.

arguments.name: NCAN=
arguments.description: Specifies the number of canonical variables to compute.

arguments.name: NOCLASSIFY
arguments.description: Suppresses the resubstitution classification of the input DATA= data set.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Suppresses the normal display of results.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: Creates an output SAS data set containing all the data from the DATA= data set, plus the posterior probabilities and the class into which each observation is classified by resubstitution.

arguments.name: OUTCROSS=
arguments.description: Creates an output SAS data set containing all the data from the DATA= data set, plus the posterior probabilities and the class into which each observation is classified by cross validation.

arguments.name: OUTD=
arguments.description: Creates an output SAS data set containing all the data from the DATA= data set, plus the group-specific density estimates for each observation.

arguments.name: OUTSTAT=
arguments.description: Creates an output SAS data set containing various statistics such as means, standard deviations, and correlations.

arguments.name: PCORR
arguments.description: [Displays pooled within-class correlations.

arguments.name: PCOV
arguments.description: Displays pooled within-class covariances.

arguments.name: POOL=
arguments.description: Determines whether the pooled or within-group covariance matrix is the basis of the measure of the squared distance.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: PROC DISCRIM uses the individual within-group covariance matrices in calculating the distances. Quadratic discriminant functions are computed.

arguments.name: TEST
arguments.description: When you specify METHOD=NORMAL, the option POOL=TEST requests Bartlett’s modification of the likelihood ratio test of the homogeneity of the within-group covariance matrices.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: PROC DISCRIM uses the pooled covariance matrix in calculating the (generalized) squared distances. Linear discriminant functions are computed.

arguments.name: POSTERR
arguments.description: Displays the posterior probability error-rate estimates of the classification criterion based on the classification results.

arguments.name: PSSCP
arguments.description: Displays the pooled within-class corrected SSCP matrix.

arguments.name: R=
arguments.description: Specifies a radius r value for kernel density estimation.

arguments.name: SHORT
arguments.description: Suppresses the display of certain items in the default output.

arguments.name: SIMPLE
arguments.description: Displays simple descriptive statistics for the total sample and within each class.

arguments.name: SINGULAR=
arguments.description: Specifies the criterion for determining the singularity of a matrix, where 0 < p < 1. The default is SINGULAR=1E–8.

arguments.name: SLPOOL=
arguments.description: Specifies the significance level for the test of homogeneity.

arguments.name: STDMEAN
arguments.description: Displays total-sample and pooled within-class standardized class means.

arguments.name: TCORR
arguments.description: Displays total-sample correlations.

arguments.name: TCOV
arguments.description: Displays total-sample covariances.

arguments.name: TESTDATA=
arguments.description: Names an ordinary SAS data set with observations that are to be classified.

arguments.name: TESTLIST
arguments.description: Lists classification results for all observations in the TESTDATA= data set.

arguments.name: TESTLISTERR
arguments.description: Lists only misclassified observations in the TESTDATA= data set but only if a TESTCLASS statement is also used.

arguments.name: TESTOUT=
arguments.description: Creates an output SAS data set containing all the data from the TESTDATA= data set, plus the posterior probabilities and the class into which each observation is classified.

arguments.name: TESTOUTD=
arguments.description: Creates an output SAS data set containing all the data from the TESTDATA= data set, plus the posterior probabilities and the class into which each observation is classified. When you specify the CANONICAL option, the data set also contains new variables with canonical variable scores.

arguments.name: THRESHOLD=
arguments.description: Specifies the minimum acceptable posterior probability for classification, where 0 ≤ P<=1.

arguments.name: TSSCP
arguments.description: Displays the total-sample corrected SSCP matrix.

arguments.name: WCORR
arguments.description: Displays within-class correlations for each class level.

arguments.name: WCOV
arguments.description: Displays within-class covariances for each class level.

arguments.name: WSSCP
arguments.description: Displays the within-class corrected SSCP matrix for each class level.

statements.name: BY
statements.description: Obtains separate analyses on observations in groups defined by the BY variables.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: Specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.

arguments.name: NOTSORTED
arguments.description: Specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order.

statements.name: CLASS
statements.description: The values of the classification variable define the groups for analysis. Class levels are determined by the formatted values of the CLASS variable. The specified variable can be numeric or character. A CLASS statement is required.

statements.name: FREQ
statements.description: If one variable in your data set represents the frequency of occurrence for the other values in the observation, specify the variable’s name in a FREQ statement. The procedure then treats the data set as if each observation appears ni times, where ni is the value of the FREQ variable for observation i.

statements.name: ID
statements.description: The ID statement is effective only when you specify the LIST or LISTERR option in the PROC DISCRIM statement. When the DISCRIM procedure displays the classification results, the ID variable (rather than the observation number) is displayed for each observation.

statements.name: PRIORS
statements.description: The PRIORS statement specifies the prior probabilities of group membership. For other than equal or proportional priors, specify the prior probability for each level of the classification variable.

arguments.name: EQUAL
arguments.description: Sets the prior probabilities equal.

arguments.name: PROPORTIONAL
arguments.description: Sets the prior probabilities proportional to the sample sizes.

statements.name: TESTCLASS
statements.description: The TESTCLASS statement names the variable in the TESTDATA= data set that is used to determine whether an observation in the TESTDATA= data set is misclassified.

statements.name: TESTFREQ
statements.description: If a variable in the TESTDATA= data set represents the frequency of occurrence of the other values in the observation, include the variable’s name in a TESTFREQ statement. The procedure then treats the data set as if each observation appears n times, where n is the value of the TESTFREQ variable for the observation.

statements.name: TESTID
statements.description: The TESTID statement is effective only when you specify the TESTLIST or TESTLISTERR option in the PROC DISCRIM statement. When the DISCRIM procedure displays the classification results for the TESTDATA= data set, the TESTID variable (rather than the observation number) is displayed for each observation.

statements.name: VAR
statements.description: VAR variable(s); The VAR statement specifies the quantitative variables to be included in the analysis. The default is all numeric variables not listed in other statements.

statements.name: WEIGHT
statements.description: To use relative weights for each observation in the input data set, place the weights in a variable in the data set and specify the name in a WEIGHT statement. This is often done when the variance associated with each observation is different and the values of the weight variable are proportional to the reciprocals of the variances. If the value of the WEIGHT variable is missing or is less than zero, then a value of zero for the weight is used.
